en: Interview with Jennifer Franklin, 2019-11-07

Interview with Jennifer Franklin, professor with the Forestry, Wildlife and Fisheries department of UT. Franklin discusses the elements of the 2016 wildfires that led to its severity. She also provides information of the regeneration of the forest, with particular focus on the various kinds of trees in the area. This is a representative quote from the interview: "Going up to those really high intensity sights, there was no organic matter at all. It was bare earth."

motion pictures (visual works)

Description

Interview with Jennifer Franklin, professor with the Forestry, Wildlife and Fisheries department of UT. Franklin discusses the elements of the 2016 wildfires that led to its severity. She also provides information of the regeneration of the forest, with particular focus on the various kinds of trees in the area. This is a representative quote from the interview: "Going up to those really high intensity sights, there was no organic matter at all. It was bare earth."

Interview with Jennifer Franklin, 2019-11-07 -- Great Smoky Mountains National Park
Captions in English
Bibliographic Description in MODS
Interview with Jennifer Franklin, 2019-11-07
Interview Questions
How long have you lived in East Tennessee?
Can you tell us what brought you here and what your career path has been like since?
Can you tell us about the focus of your research before the fire?
When did you first become aware of the fire on Chimney Tops?
Did you study any of the other fires that were occurring during that fall?
What was your first reaction to hearing about the Chimney Tops II fire?
What were the dynamics that caused the Chimney Tops II fire to become so severe?
What is a ground fire and how does that propel the fire?
When you heard about the fire having reached Gatlinburg, what was your reaction?
In the aftermath, how did you think the fire would affect your research?
Did you have any conversations with your colleagues or others about the fire?
Where did you go into the park to see the effects of the fire?
Did you go to a specific plot to study the effects?
Was there anything surprising about the aftereffects?
How does a high intensity burn site differ from a more typical ground fire?
What accounted for the patchiness of the fire?
What was your decision to study the impact of the fire on the Smokies?
What made this fire unique for this area?
Can you tell us about the methodologies of your research?
What have you discovered so far?
What is the diversity of trees that are regrowing like?
Have you noticed an increase of invasive species after the fire?
Can you tell us where you research plots are located?
Can you tell us where you research plots are located?
Has any part of your research surprised you so far?
Can you explain some impacts of your research on the understanding of wildfires?
What tree species are surviving?
What public impacts can be taken from your research?
Were there any long term damages or runoff?
Is another similar fire likely to happen again?
Did climate change have a role in causing this fire?
Do you have other research projects envisioned that are tied to the fire?
What does fire behavior research entail?
Is there anything else you would like to share?
